column1: Persons affected by Bartter syndrome lose too much sodium through the urine.
Bartter syndrome is usually suspected when a blood test finds a low level of potassium in the blood.
Unlike other forms of kidney disease, this condition does not cause high blood pressure.

Other signs of this syndrome include: - High levels of potassium, calcium, and chloride in the urine - High levels of the hormones renin and aldosterone in the blood - Low blood chloride - Metabolic alkalosis These same signs and symptoms can also occur in people who take too many diuretics (water pills) or laxatives.
Biopsy of the kidney may be done to confirm Bartter syndrome.
A biopsy is a medical procedure that removes a small piece of kidney tissue for examination.
Infants who have severe growth failure may grow normally with treatment.
Most patients remain well with ongoing treatment, though some develop kidney failure.
